The distribution of the initial generations indeed can affect the 
course o=
f evolution.  However, it is difficult to make informed a 
priori decisions=
 about the initial population before an experiment is 
run, because little =
may be known about the structure of the search 
space.  However, I believe =
there has been work on the composition of 
initial populations in GAs and t=
he right random distribution (e.g. 
uniform vs. normal, or something else) =
of individuals in that 
population to best cover the search space.  

The i=
dea that you might create many initial populations and evaluate 
all of the=
m is not buying any obvious advantage because you still end 
up having to e=
valuate all those initial populations.  For example, 
let's say that the po=
pulation size is 100.  Then if you generate 10 
initial populations, you en=
d up evaluating 1,000 individuals before 
deciding in which population to i=
nvest further.  On the other hand, 
if you start with simply one population=
, then after 1,000 evaluatins 
you will have proceeded 10 generations.  So =
the question is, which 
was more effective, evaluating 10 random population=
s, or evaluating 
10 generations of evolutionary search?  

The answer is n=
ot obvious because the dynamics of both strategies are 
quite complex and d=
omain-dependent.  One could argue for the 
advantages of either.  However, =
what can be said is that there is no 
knock-down reason that having multipl=
e initial populations will 
improve efficiency.  

Note that search efficie=
ncy is generally considered to be number of 
evaluations, so if 1,000 evalu=
ations are added at the get-go, some 
consequence would need to make up for=
 that initial investment. 

ken

he NEAT params are focused on transition to

 as such appear neutral wrt generation zero, except

ion size.
